subject: Education

title: Paulo Freire: Teaching as a Political Act
description: A micro-lesson that makes Paulo Freire: Teaching as a Political Act usable.

hook.text: Brazil's military government exiled Paulo Freire for teaching peasants to read. Literacy was too powerful to allow.

buildup.text: Freire developed critical pedagogy: students learn by analyzing their own oppression, not by memorizing textbook facts.

discovery.text: His method: show peasants a picture of their lives, discuss it, then teach the words that name their reality. Literacy

twist.text: Pedagogy of the Oppressed is banned in parts of the US today. Some states call his ideas 'critical race theory.'

climax.text: Freire proved that all education is political. The question isn't whether schools teach values, but whose values they

punchline.text: Teaching literacy is never just about reading. It's about who gets to speak.

quiz.question: What was central to Freire's critical pedagogy?
options: Students analyzing their own social reality as part of learning
